required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: the Role of Alpha-fetoprotein in the Prediction of Early Pregnancy Failure

brief_summary.textblock: Early pregnancy loss is a common obstetric complication and is often preceded by vaginal bleeding. Î±-fetoprotein (AFP) is produced by the yolk sac and later in the fetal liver and can be measured as early as the fifth week of gestation. Our study is to determine if alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) concentration in vaginal blood, in the setting of dissolved fetal tissue, is significantly higher than its concentration in the maternal serum.

primary_outcome.measure: Vaginal blood AFP/ maternal serum AFP ratio
primary_outcome.description: Comparing AFP concentration in the vaginal blood with the AFP concentration in the maternal blood

arm_group.description: Includes 15 patients with severe vaginal bleeding or part of the product of conception pass through the cervix, cx opened, and -ve fetal pulse.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Group B (with vaginal bleeding during cerclage placement):
arm_group.description: Includes 15 patients with vaginal bleeding during cerclage

study_pop.textblock: A total of 30 pregnant women aged 18-40 years in the first or the second trimester with symptoms of possible pregnancy failure (vaginal bleeding).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Women in the reproductive-age group between 18 to 39 years old.
2. Women with single intra-uterine pregnancy.
3. Women with gestation age correctly dated by trans vaginal at the time of the first or second trimester.
4. Women who are medically free.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Women with twin or multiple pregnancies.
2. Threatened abortion with +ve fetal pulsation.
3. anembryonic pregnancy, complete vesicular mole.
4. Women with a gestation age of more than 25 weeks.
5. Women with s medical diseases such as diabetes, liver cancer, ovarian cancer, hepatitis, renal cell carcinoma.

responsible_party.investigator_title: assistant lecture of obstetrics and gynecology
